instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
Liquid damage. Lots of minor blue everywhere.
components around <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> has minor corrosion. <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> looks like it might have been hit the hardest.
When plugged in I get 5.12v-5.16v on each port. No amps.

Looking around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> I noticed <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P5VG3S</SIGNAL> had .02v to ground. Traced it back to <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>. Replaced that and short was gone. Plugged in the board and had 5v with .3 amps then 19.8v with 0 amps. Checked a different port and it was back to 5v 0 amps. Checked  <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P5VG3S</SIGNAL> again and back to .04v to ground.
Short is on pins 6,7,8 of <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>. so something on <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> at .016v. Removed <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> to confirm not on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

The only thing with serious corrosion on <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> was pin 22 of j5100. Removed connector and 4 connecting caps but no change.

Safe to inject <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
If I remove <CHIP>U8110</CHIP> the short goes to .7v. Poking around I found a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_USBC</SIGNAL>. If I also remove rb706, rb701, <RESISTOR>R3506</RESISTOR>, and <RESISTOR>R3501</RESISTOR> - then my short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> goes away.

Pulled a replacement for <CHIP>U8110</CHIP> from an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Is this ok?
Short is gone - .295v to ground on <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>.

replaced <CHIP>U3500</CHIP>, ub700, qb701, and q3501to eliminate short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_USBC</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
Plugged in and fried <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> again...
5v, 40amps then 19v 0amps. unplugged and plugged again - 5v 0amps.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> - .02v to ground. (not <CHIP>U8110</CHIP> this time). 

<SIGNAL>PP5V_USBC</SIGNAL> - no short.

Stopping on this until I get a reply... Please help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
Allow 15-20s after power removed, before measuring diode mode.

Be sure R/<CAPACITOR>C7609</CAPACITOR> are good, as traces/solders too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
R/<CAPACITOR>C7609</CAPACITOR> are good, same with traces. 

Short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> is 0.6 ohms..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message: Lift L7600 and check where the short remains.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message: pin 1

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
That is the system side.
Start injecting 1V and go up slowly, if needed.
You may need 20A PSU, to heat something...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8400</CHIP> got hot. Replaced and board is no longer pulling amps from psu.
pin 1 of L7600 is only up to 0.084v to ground.

Edit - now its at .340v... going to test the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
fried <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> again.. same as before. 
What could keep shorting things out on this line?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message: Check <RESISTOR>R7609</RESISTOR>/65 and replace <CAPACITOR>C7609</CAPACITOR>, <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>/50.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
replaced: 
<RESISTOR>R7609</RESISTOR>/65 
<CAPACITOR>C7609</CAPACITOR>
<CHIP>U7600</CHIP>
<CHIP>U7650</CHIP>

Short was on <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> again. When testing the board I use naked board out of case with only one charging port attached. 

Should I go ahead and apply power again or test something else prior? 
Any chance charging chips are somehow frying this line?

<RESISTOR>R7678</RESISTOR> shows as 8.3k. Replaced and get the same. Other board starts at 8k and climbs to 40k..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7677</RESISTOR>/78/79 are all good, as their traces too.
Open feedback network can cause overvoltage on <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL>!!!

High value resistors must be checked out of board.
Onboard measurment will cause lower reading than nominal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7677</RESISTOR>/78/79 are all good. 

Applied power - 5v .25a then 19v .08a up to .21a then back to .08a. This time it doesn't short and when plugged back in it does the same thing. 
5.135v on <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message: Check which voltage missing in power on sequence.

threads.message:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is slightly low at - 2.925v


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.6v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> - 12.6v

PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3HRTC - 12.6v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4SW</SIGNAL> - 5.135v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4SW_ISNS</SIGNAL> - 0v"
Check <RESISTOR>R5950</RESISTOR> and traces; be sure no short there.

Try to understand a schematic to earn time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
For <RESISTOR>R5950</RESISTOR> there is nothing there. Other schematics have this listed as OMIT.
Doesnt look like it's missing, just never had anything. same with <CHIP>U5710</CHIP>/00
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4SW</SIGNAL> is 0v.. I must have measured something else. But this system has nothing attached related to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4SW</SIGNAL> so that shouldnt be a problem?

That just leaves <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> - 2.925v?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
Im actually getting 0v on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4SW</SIGNAL>. Looked around and noticed <RESISTOR>R3501</RESISTOR>/06 were bad. Replaced these and <CHIP>U3500</CHIP>/<TRANSISTOR>Q3501</TRANSISTOR> but still nothing on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4SW</SIGNAL>. 
Doesnt see shorted - .293v to ground. 
Could this be <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/3200?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power - 5v
threads.message:
Any other voltage from the ones mentioned before dissapeared now?
<SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> still present?
